title-group.article-title: Phosphatase and Tensin Homolog (PTEN) Gene Mutations and Autism: Literature Review and a Case Report of a Patient With Cowden Syndrome, Autistic Disorder, and Epilepsy

abstract.p: Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) gene mutations are associated with a spectrum of clinical disorders characterized by skin lesions, macrocephaly, hamartomatous overgrowth of tissues, and an increased risk of cancers. Autism has rarely been described in association with these variable clinical features. At present, 24 patients with phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutation, autism, macrocephaly, and some clinical findings described in phosphatase and tensin homolog syndromes have been reported in the literature. We describe a 14-year-old boy with autistic disorder, focal epilepsy, severe and progressive macrocephaly, and multiple papular skin lesions and palmoplantar punctate keratoses, characteristic of Cowden syndrome. The boy has a de novo phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutation. Our patient is the first case described to present a typical Cowden syndrome and autism associated with epilepsy.

body.p: Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) tumor suppressor on chromosome 10 gene encodes a dual-specificity phosphatase that mediates cell cycle arrest and apoptosis; it is localized on chromosome band 10q23. Phosphatase and tensin homolog germline mutations have been implicated in a group of related tumor syndromes with autosomal dominant inheritance and highly variable expression, known as the “phosphatase and tensin homolog hamartoma tumor syndromes,” and including Cowden syndrome, Bannayan-Riley-Ruvalcaba syndrome, Proteus syndrome and Proteus-like conditions, Lhermitte-Duclos disease, and Juvenile Polyposis syndrome. These syndromes may present different symptoms affecting the central nervous system, the skin, and the intestine with increased risk for malignancies.1

Cowden syndrome is a multisystem disorder involving increased risk for malignancies, especially breast and thyroid cancer, benign hamartomatous overgrowth of mucocutaneous, breast, thyroid, or intestinal tissues and macrocephaly. Skin lesions and hamartomas usually appear by the age of 20 years. In 2008 the National Comprehensive Cancer Network revised the Cowden syndrome diagnostic criteria proposing the use of pathognomonic, major and minor criteria (Table 1). An accurate clinical observation, with a careful and regular surveillance of affected patients, is necessary to evaluate the risk of developing malignancies.2

body.p: Several recent reports have identified heterozygous germline phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutations also in children with autism spectrum disorder, macrocephaly, and sometimes clinical features of hamartoma tumor syndromes. To date, 24 cases with these features and the following common clinical aspects have been described in the literature: prevalence of male gender; birth weight, length, and head circumference at upper limits; and association with a possible positive family history for phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutations and/or familial macrocephaly.3–15

A summary of the clinical pictures of the reported cases is provided in Table 2; none of the patients reported in the literature so far met the clinical diagnostic criteria of Cowden syndrome. We point out that according to 2008 National Comprehensive Cancer Network criteria, the case described by Goffin in 2001 could not receive a diagnosis of Cowden syndrome. In fact he presented only one major (macrocephaly) and one minor (mental retardation) criterion.7 We mention that macrocephaly is relatively common in autism but usually without a dramatic trend. We describe the first patient with autistic disorder, severe and progressive macrocephaly, skin lesions, focal epilepsy, and a phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutation who indeed meets the clinical diagnostic criteria of Cowden syndrome.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: The patient is a boy aged 14. His family history was positive for macrocephaly, dysthyroidism, gastrointestinal cancers, autism, and behavioral and psychiatric disorders (Figure 1).

During pregnancy, the boy’s head circumference was at upper limits. He was born at term by induced delivery for absent uterine contractions and umbilical cord wrapped around the neck. His weight at birth was 3800 g (90th percentile), length 53 cm (75th-90th percentile), and head circumference 36 cm (90th percentile). His psychomotor development was normal except for a mild speech delay up to 36 months, when the parents noticed a language regression and a change in behavior characterized by loss of social interaction, stereotyped movements, and loss of eye contact. Within 5 years of age head circumference was upper 98th percentile (57.5 cm); at the age of 10 it was 59 cm (>98th percentile). High-resolution karyotype and genetic tests for fragile X syndrome and for the 15q11.2 region were normal. Cerebral magnetic resonance imaging disclosed right periventricular hyperintensity probably due to a remote hypoxic-ischemic insult, confirmed by the second and third magnetic resonance imaging at ages 6 and 12, respectively. A genetic counseling and phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) molecular analysis for point mutations and exon/gene deletions performed by a combination of denaturing high-performance liquid chromatography and multiple ligation-dependent probe amplification was performed when the patient was 6 years old and an exon 2 deletion was detected. The same deletion was not identified in the patient’s healthy parents and the healthy older sister.

When the boy was 8 years old, 2 focal epileptic seizures occurred during wakefulness. The first seizure was characterized by pallor and hypotonia; the second one by vomiting, cyanosis, hypotonia, and loss of contact, lasting some minutes. Electroencephalogram recordings showed focal spike-wave complexes over the left temporal regions. A treatment with valproic acid was started. After that, seizures no longer occurred.

At the clinical observation performed when the patient was 12 years old, he showed macrocephaly (>98th percentile, 60 cm), dysmorphic signs as abducted auricular pavilions, prominent forehead, flat feet, knock-knee, multiple mucocutaneous papules, and palmoplantar punctate keratoses. Skin examination revealed flesh-colored lesions, 1 to 3 mm diameter, resembling flat warts localized on the dorsum of hands and feet and on the proximal upper extremities. Similar lesions affected the lips also. Translucent hard papules, 2 to 4 mm in diameter, with a central depression distributed symmetrically on the palms and soles were noted.

The language was absent; impairment of symbolic functions, several stereotyped movements (such as head banging, hand flapping, and body rocking) and a developmental disorder were evident. Neuropsychological evaluation showed an autistic disorder (Childhood Autism Rating Scale, Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule) and a profound mental retardation according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition, Text Revision (Leiter-R Scale).

Electroencephalogram recording showed that paroxysmal multifocal spike-waves were diffuse and subcontinuous during sleep over the left frontocentrotemporal regions. Recently, a photoparoxysmal response was detected (Figure 2).

caption.p: Electroencephalogram recording during non–rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep showing subcontinuous focal spike-waves over the left frontocentrotemporal regions; during wakefulness a photoparoxysmal response.

sec.p: Histological examination of a papule localized on the arm showed focal prominent epidermal hyperplasia that at its periphery is demarcated by elongated rete ridges; foci of wedge-shaped hypergranulosis with compact orthokeratosis; dilated vessels in the papillary dermis.

Skin lesions permitted diagnosis of Cowden syndrome16 (Table 1). Laboratory testing revealed a moderate increase of thyrotrophin-stimulating hormone and free triiodothyronine and uncertain values for anti-endomysial antibodies with positivity for human leukocyte antigen (HLA) haplotypes (HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8) associated with celiac disease. The patient presents either constipation or diarrhetic bowel. We suggested the recommended follow-up for increased risk of malignancies in Cowden syndrome.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our patient is the first case described in the literature to present simultaneously Cowden syndrome, autistic disorder, and epilepsy. None of the patients affected by autism and reported in the literature to date met the clinical diagnostic criteria of Cowden syndrome, probably because they were too young (aged between 16 months and 18 years) and some pathognomonic signs, such as skin lesions and hamartomas, usually appear later.3–15

In our case, the concurrent presence of severe and progressive macrocephaly and autism led us to investigate phosphatase and tensin homolog gene and later to study in depth skin lesions and to definitively make the diagnosis of Cowden syndrome. Although the family history was positive for macrocephaly, dysthyroidism, cancers, and autism, phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutation in the proband resulted de novo.

Epilepsy occurs frequently in patients with autism and also in those with associated macrocephaly.17 It has been described that mental retardation, cerebral lesions and rare diseases associated with autism increase the risk of seizures. Moreover, in idiopathic autism, seizure occurrence remains higher than in general population, suggesting that autism itself increases the risk of epilepsy. In these cases, seizures could represent an epiphenomenon of a cerebral dysfunction independent of apparent lesions and do not seem to play a pathogenetic role in autism, but they can worsen the prognosis for behavior and cognition.18 Our patient presented 2 focal seizures that we controlled by means of antiepileptic treatment and which could be related to autism, to phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) gene mutation, to perhaps a prenatal-perinatal injury in a macrosomic fetus or to all these findings combined.

We remark that in the literature there are no cases described of Cowden syndrome and autism with epilepsy or seizures. At the same time, only one of the described cases, showing phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutation and autism, presented a severe epilepsy characterized by infantile spasms.11 At present, we need to study a larger cohort of cases to verify the hypothesis of a different prevalence of epilepsy in autism linked to phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutation with respect to idiopathic autism.

The prevalence of Cowden syndrome has been estimated to be nearly 1/200 000; germline mutations in phosphatase and tensin homolog gene are generally reported to be found in 80% of patients with this syndrome.19 On the contrary, there are no data about the frequency of phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutations in the general population, or about the prevalence of autism spectrum disorders in people with a phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutation. To date, it has not been possible to determine if the occurrence of autism is greater in patients with phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutation than in the general population. If a higher occurrence will be demonstrated, we could hypothesize a role of the phosphatase and tensin homolog gene in the brain development of patients with autism.

The genetic component of autism is complex and includes known chromosomal abnormalities, rare monogenic diseases and copy number variants.20 Since the list of described genetic and metabolic conditions that are associated with autism is quite extensive and continued advances in genetic technology expand the diagnostic options available for these evaluations,21 it is important to utilize a diagnostic protocol to exclude heterogeneous pathologies associated with autism. For example, phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutation testing should be considered for patients with autism only in cases with a severe and progressive macrocephaly.3–5,8–11,13,14

In conclusion, it seems important to report all new cases affected by phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutation or Cowden syndrome for 2 reasons. First, it is relevant to detail all symptoms, most of all dermatologic, to allow for an early diagnosis as in our patient and we would like to stress the early onset of palmoplantar punctate keratoses since it has been suggested that this clinical presentation may be an initial cutaneous sign of phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutation. Second, also neurological and psychiatric features should be reported regularly and thoroughly in patients affected by phosphatase and tensin homolog gene mutations and autism because, as reported in our case, autism and epileptic seizures need an early diagnosis to ensure an adequate rehabilitative and pharmacologic treatment.
